learning_outcomes.description: Identify major concepts and practitioners in Australian and international contemporary performance.
Understand the differences between analysing dramatic scripts and contemporary performances (that are often multidisciplinary).

Understand the critical principles of postmodernism, postcolonialism, postdramatic theory, posthuman theory, and postfeminist and postcapitalist discourse; and be able to apply them to the creation and analysis of contemporary performance.
Understand the role of performance as an expression of and response to contemporary social and political contexts.
Employ appropriate research tools and critical reasoning to analyse texts, performances and performative processes in both theatre and non-theatre environments.
Work collaboratively to create a unique group performance that develops applied industry skills.

assessments.due_date:
2/03/2026 - 11/05/2026

25/05/2026 - 25/05/2026

This is an in-person assessment completed during normal contact hours, including a 100-word in-class written activity.
assessments.category: Participation/ Student contribution, Reflection, Tutorial/ Problem Set
assessments.task_description:
This task assesses your engagement with the course across the Semester. Each week, your engagement with your course content and the tutorial activity (weeks 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 11) is worth 3%. 

For the first 2% of your mark between weeks 2 and 11, you will be assessed on the basis of three components: preparation for class; engagement with the learning activities in class; and respectful peer collaboration. You must bring a copy of the relevant text (e-copies are acceptable) and any additional material to every tutorial, and you must have read them at least once. Attendance itself is not sufficient to constitute 'participation'. Participation means willing involvement, active engagement with the text and the tasks at hand, asking questions, working well in groups, and demonstrating evidence of having listened to the lectures. To receive full marks, your tutor will need to see evidence of you having engaged with this full spectrum of activity.

For the final 1% of your weekly mark between weeks 2 and 11, you will write 100 words in class, responding to a specific prompt that draws on the lecture content and set texts (critical and performance). Some responses will require responses to visual and/or audio-visual material, and you will be provided with a worksheet to write on.

Up to an additional 3% of marks is available for responding to a written prompt on a provided worksheet in the week 13 lecture. This may consist of short-answer questions of up to 100 words.

Acting ability is not assessed. It is your responsibility to ensure that your attendance has been recorded. 

If you are absent from your tutorial through documented illness or other documented circumstances beyond your control, and supply this documentation to your tutor, you will receive a pass mark (in the range of a four) for that week. You may also be able to respond to the class activities and receive additional marks. Students will receive written feedback each week.

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Late submission is not possible for this piece of assessment.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.task_description:
• This essay is designed to enable you to demonstrate your acquired knowledge and research skills by writing on a specific aspect of contemporary drama in relation to postcolonial theatre.

You will write a 2000-word essay in response to the stimulus below, which will assess your ability to:

  • produce a relevant and compelling argument
  • provide an analytic approach to the topic and its relevant issues
  • provide evidence from the text and secondary material to support this argument.

Essay question: Discuss how postcolonialism and/or decolonisation intersect with postmodernism in contemporary theatre and performance, with reference to two pieces of contemporary drama.

You need to choose one of the two set texts from our postcolonialism module, alongside one additional text. Your additional text can come from the supplied list, or you may choose your own text; if you choose your own additional text, you need to confirm its suitability with the course convenor by the end of Week Five.

Set texts (choose one):

Black Medea by Wesley Enoch OR

seven methods for killing kylie jenner by Jasmine Lee-Jones

AND

Suggested texts (choose one from below, or something of your own choosing):

An Octoroon by Branden Jacobs-Jenkins, OR

Yellow Face by David Henry Hwang, OR

Kill the Messenger by Nakkiah Lui, OR

Burgerz by Travis Alabanza

The referencing style used for Drama assignments is MLA, 9th edition.

A detailed assignment brief will be provided via Blackboard at the beginning of Semester. 

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.due_date:
18/05/2026

Performances due in the tutorial. Performance rationale due in week 11 via Blackboard.
assessments.task_description:
The group performance project is designed to enable you to demonstrate your familiarity with one of the final two ‘posts’ that we studied in class this semester, and to apply that thinking to the understanding of postdramatic theatre that we have focused on throughout the course. In groups of four to six, you are required to devise a performance based on one set of the paired texts studied from weeks 7 to 11, using postdramatic techniques to explore your chosen texts, and their associated 'post' identifier.

·       Postfeminism

·       Posthumanism

There is a 10-minute maximum performance time for this assignment. This short piece will be performed for other DRAM2040 students in Week 12. A 100-word performance rationale will be submitted by each group in week 11 outlining the aims of their performance. You will be provided with some technical support in the performance of your projects, with access to sound, lighting and video performance technology. You will also have access to rehearsal time in tutorials after the mid-semester break.

Group members will each receive the same grade out of 35 for the performance. The remaining five marks will be determined through a peer-accountability survey, where you will be required to provide feedback on the work of your peers against criteria in BuddyCheck by the end of week 12. If you do not participate in the BuddyCheck survey, you will not receive the peer-accountability marks. 

A detailed assignment brief will be made available via Blackboard.

Recording of Oral and Practical Assessment

All presentations will be recorded for marking purposes via recording facilities available where the assessment takes place (eg. ECHO360, Zoom, camera device). Recordings will be retained by the School of Communication and Arts for at least 12 months from the release of the final grade for the course. Recordings will be stored in a secure manner and will only be accessed by authorised school staff for the purposes of:

  • Moderation of marking;
  • Provision of feedback to the student(s) recorded; and/or
  • Re-marking following a successful re-mark application.


This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
